data.question: What are the names of the two novel microporous frameworks reported for highly selective capture of C2H2?
Which gases are BSF-3 and BSF-3-Co designed to separate C2H2 from?
What functionality contributes to the high C2H2 capacity and remarkable C2H2/CO2 selectivity in BSF-3 and BSF-3-Co?
data.answer: The unique anionic boron cluster functionality and the suitable pore size with cooperative proton-hydride dihydrogen bonding sites.

data.question: What are the BET surface areas of BSF-3 and BSF-3-Co, respectively?
data.answer: BSF-3 has a BET surface area of 458 m2 g@1, and BSF-3-Co has a BET surface area of 437 m2 g@1.

data.question: What is the role of the anionic boron cluster functionality in the separation process?
data.answer: The anionic boron cluster functionality enhances the interaction with C2H2 through multiple proton-hydride dihydrogen bonds, leading to high C2H2 binding affinity and capture capacity.

data.question: How do BSF-3 and BSF-3-Co compare in terms of C2H2 uptake under 1 bar and 298 K?
data.answer: BSF-3 has a C2H2 uptake of 3.59 mmol g@1, and BSF-3-Co has a C2H2 uptake of 3.85 mmol g@1.

data.question: What is the significance of the cooperative dihydrogen bonding sites in BSF-3 and BSF-3-Co?
data.answer: The cooperative dihydrogen bonding sites enhance the affinity towards C2H2 and reduce interactions with CO2 and C2H4, leading to high selectivity and capacity for C2H2 capture.

data.question: How does the pore size and chemistry of BSF-3 and BSF-3-Co contribute to their gas separation performance?
data.answer: The fine-tuning of pore size and chemistry, including the alignment of closo-dodecaborate anions inside the channels, allows for the selective adsorption of C2H2 over CO2 and C2H4 by creating cooperative dihydrogen bonding sites.

data.question: Why is the C2H2/CO2 selectivity of BSF-3 considered remarkable compared to other materials?
data.answer: The C2H2/CO2 selectivity of BSF-3 is higher than many leading materials due to its unique anionic boron cluster functionality and optimized pore size, which provide strong and selective interactions with C2H2.

data.question: What experimental methods were used to confirm the structure and properties of BSF-3 and BSF-3-Co?
data.answer: Single crystal diffraction analysis, gas adsorption studies, IR spectroscopy, TGA analysis, EPR spectroscopy, and dynamic breakthrough experiments were used.

data.question: How do the adsorption isotherms of BSF-3 and BSF-3-Co at different temperatures contribute to understanding their gas separation performance?
data.answer: The adsorption isotherms at different temperatures, showing type I isotherms, help in calculating the isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Qst) for C2H2, CO2, and C2H4, providing insights into the preferential adsorption of C2H2 over CO2 and C2H4.

data.question: What role does the pore size distribution play in the gas separation efficiency of BSF-3 and BSF-3-Co?
data.answer: The pore size distribution, calculated from N2 adsorption, indicates analogous porous characteristics between BSF-3 and BSF-3-Co, which are crucial for their high gas separation efficiency by ensuring the accessibility of pores to specific gas molecules.
